newsitem.title: USA: IBM strong Q1 fueled by growth businesses.
newsitem.headline: IBM strong Q1 fueled by growth businesses.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp on Wednesday reported better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, surpassing most Wall Street estimates, as its faster-growing businesses offset a decline in mainframes, minicomputers and workstations.
It said its revenues rose five percent to $17.3 billion compared with the first quarter of 1996, but they were up nine percent in constant currency terms, before the impact of the stronger dollar.

IBM said first-quarter net earnings were $1.2 billion, or $2.37 per share, compared with $2.21 per share in the first quarter of 1996, excluding a charge to cover costs related to two acquisitions in March 1996. Including the charge, year-ago first-quarter earnings were $1.41 per share.
The First Call consensus earnings estimate for the first quarter of 1997 was $2.28 per share.

Lou Gerstner, IBM chairman and chief executive, said: "As expected, our server business was adversely affected by product transitions, most notably within our System/390 division, and by ongoing weakness in Europe."
He said the weakness in Europe hurt sales of IBM's AS/400 minicomputer systems. His reference to System/390 alludes to the company's mainframe business.
But he said excellent results in fast-growing businesses more than offset weakness in server computer lines.

"We continued to see strong performance in the first quarter in fast-growth areas including services, personal computers and certain distributed software such as Lotus Notes and Tivoli systems-management products," Gerstner said.
The top IBM executive also said he was pleased by the results of the company's data-storage business.

IBM said North American revenues rose 14 percent versus the year-ago first quarter to $7.9 billion. Asia-Pacific revenues rose three percent to $3.4 billion, while Latin America rose two percent to $701 million.
Revenues from IBM's Europe/Middle East/Africa region fell seven percent to $5.3 billlion.
Excluding the effect of currency translation, Asia-Pacific revenues grew 14 percent and Europe/Middle East/Africa was up one percent.
Hardware sales totaled $7.8 billion in the first quarter, little changed from the same period of 1996, it said.
Personal computer and PC-based server computer revenues increased, while RS/6000 workstation, AS/400 minicomputer and System/390 mainframe revenues fell, the computer maker said.
Revenues from the company's storage business increased by an unspecified amount in part because of strong sales of hard disk drive products.
First-quarter services revenues reached $4.1 billion, a 28 percent increase over the same quarter of 1996. IBM said it signed services deals worth $3 billion in the first quarter.
Software revenues declined three percent to $2.9 billion in the first quarter versus the year-ago period.
Shipments of Tivoli systems management products used to manage the networked computer systems of large enterprises more than doubled year over year, it said.
The Lotus Notes installed base of users rose by about 1.7 million seats, or computer users, bringing the total installed base of computers running Lotus Notes to 11 million seats.
It said hardware revenues grew five percent on a constant currency basis, while service revenues rose 34 percent and software revenues rose two percent on that basis.

Maintenance revenues, which are largely associated with servicing IBM's vast mainframe computer business, declined eight percent year over year to $1.6 billion, while revenues from rentals and financing rose four percent to $899 million.
The total gross profit margin slipped to 38.1 percent in the first quarter from 40.9 percent in the first quarter of last year, the company said.

Total expenses in the first quarter were "essentially flat" compared with the first quarter of 1996. IBM said its expense-to-revenue ratio improved by 1.5 percentage points in the first quarter versus a year ago.
IBM's tax rate was 35.5 percent in the first quarter compared with 39.0 percent in the first quarter of 1996.
It said it spent about $2.0 billion buying back shares during the first quarter, leaving about $800 million remaining under its current share buyback authorization.
The average number of common shares outstanding was reduced to 501.7 million in the latest quarter versus 544.3 million in the year-earlier period.

IBM said its "core" debt, excluding customer financing, was unchanged from the $2.2 billion at the end of 1996. Debt supporting IBM's global credit operations rose $817 million to $21.4 billion from $20.6 billion at the end of 1996.
((-- Eric Auchard, New York newsdesk, 212-859-1736))
